cluster_relations.rel_desc: Mechanical and Metallurgical Failure and Uniform or Localized Loss of Thickness are presented as peer sections within the same list of damage mechanisms.
cluster_relations.object_entity_name: Uniform or Localized Loss of Thickness

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: DocumentStructure: listed as peer damage mechanism categories in the same section

remarks: Relation reflects document-level grouping rather than a causal or hierarchical dependency; direction is arbitrary and used only to encode co-membership.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Uniform or Localized Loss of Thickness and High Temperature Corrosion are presented as peer sections within the same list of damage mechanisms.
cluster_relations.subject_entity_name: Uniform or Localized Loss of Thickness

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: DocumentStructure: co-listed as damage mechanism categories

remarks: Relation mainly encodes co-membership in the same list; not implying any causal or structural dependency between the mechanisms.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: High Temperature Corrosion and Environment Assisted Cracking are presented as peer sections within the same list of damage mechanisms.
cluster_relations.object_class_label: Stress Corrosion and Environment Assisted Cracking Mechanisms

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: DocumentStructure: both are subsections under the same damage mechanisms section

remarks: Relation created to capture that both mechanisms are co-classified in the same document section; direction is arbitrary.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that two entities are presented or classified together as peer items within the same document section, list, or taxonomy, without implying causal, hierarchical, or structural dependency.
args.justification: All three relations use the raw predicate 'grouped_with' and descriptions state that the pairs are presented as peer sections or co-listed damage mechanism categories within the same document section. This is a symmetric, document-structure-based co-membership relation, best normalized as 'co_classified_with' to reflect co-classification rather than causality or hierarchy.
args.remark: Direction is arbitrary and represents symmetric co-classification in a document or taxonomy; semantics are purely associative, not causal or hierarchical.

args.justification: Each relation captures that two damage mechanism categories are co-listed as peer sections within the same damage mechanisms section. This is a family of relations describing co-membership or co-classification in a taxonomy or document structure, which fits a 'coclassification_relation' class.
args.remark: This class can be reused for other relations that encode co-membership in lists, tables of contents, or classification schemes, without implying hierarchy or causality.

args.justification: The relations express a non-causal, non-structural association based on being grouped together in a document or classification scheme. This fits a broad ASSOCIATION category rather than COMPOSITION, CAUSALITY, or IDENTITY.
args.remark: These are document-structure associations capturing co-occurrence in the same classification context.
